com.rcextract.minecord.sql

Class TypeConverter<I,O>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.rcextract.minecord.sql.TypeConverter<I,O>
  • Type Parameters:
    I - The input type of serialize(Object) and the output type of deserialize(Object).
    O - The input type of deserialize(Object) and the output type of serialize(Object).
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    FinalTypeConverter

    public abstract class TypeConverter<I,O>
extends Object
    A utility class designed for conversions between types an SQL server is supporting by default, and a Java type which is not implementing the DatabaseSerializable interface. This is like an implementation of the SQLObjectConverter API of a class but outside it.

    To create a TypeConverter, you should first create a class inheriting it. It can be an anonymous class. Then, specify the types you want to convert between, and implement the method serialize(Object) and deserialize(Object). Be careful that the type parameter I is the input type for serialize(Object) and O is the input type for deserialize(Object). Below is an example of TypeConverter between UUID and String: public class ExampleConverter extends TypeConverter { public ExampleConverter() { super(UUID.class, String.class); } public String serialize(UUID uuid) { return uuid.toString(); } public UUID deserialize(String string) { return UUID.fromString(string); } }

    To make it work for an SQLObjectConverter, get the instance and do connector.getConverters().add(converter); where connector is the SQLObjectConverter instance and the converter is the TypeConverter instance. If you want all SQLObjectConverter instances to have the TypeConverter at construction, add it to the DEFAULT_CONVERTERS ComparativeSet constant which is accessible through getDefaultConvertors.

    If the SQLObjectConverter instance already contains a TypeConverter with the same input or output type as what you are providing, it will not be added. Even converters with only either the same input type or the output type is not allowed, because the SQLObjectConnector does not know which one to use.

    SQLObjectConverter supports multiple times of serialization or deserialization on the same object. This means an OfflinePlayer can first be serialized to UUID with TypeConverter, then can be again serialized from UUID to String with TypeConverter.
